  • • Increased 24-hour urinary excretion of copper (the most specific screening test) (Option C) Increase in hepatic Copper content (the most sensitive and accurate test) A decrease in serum ceruloplasmin (Option A) Kayser - Fleischer rings
  • • Genetic testing for mutations in the ATPZB gene Serum copper levels are of no diagnostic use since they may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of the disease.
  • (Option D) Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene, which codes for the enzyme copper-transporting ATPase present on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page No 850.

questions.text: A patient presents with flank pain and hematuria. The histopathology Image of the patient is provided. Based on the clinical presentation and histological findings, which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is Option 4. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma

The given histological image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. It can be identified by the presence of pale eosinophilic cells arranged in the form of solid sheets with some cells having a perinuclear halo.
  • Chromophobe carcinoma is thought to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts.
  • It is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus.
  • It shows large cells having a plant-cell-Hike appearance. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.
  • Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy.
  • It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 950, 951.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient comes with complaints of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions. A family history of brain tumors and kidney tumors is present. MRI showed a cerebellar mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical history of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions along with the family history of brain tumors and kidney tumors is suggestive of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.
  • (VHL) VHL Syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina.
  • Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons.
  • Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 292, 1302.

questions.text: A female complaints of dysuria since 4 days associated with pelvic pain and abnormal vaginal discharge. Pap smear image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of dysuria, pelvic pain, and abnormal vaginal discharge and the above pap smear shows large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo which is suggestive of koilocytes, which is a characteristic feature of infection caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).
Other features that can also be seen in histology are:
  • Perinuclear halo
  • Multinucleation Orangeophilic (Keratinisation) cytoplasm
  • Acanthosis
  • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate


Reference: Krawczyk E, Suprynowicz FA, Liu X, Dai Y, Hartmann DP, Hanover J, Schlegel R. Koilocytosis: a cooperative interaction between the human papillomavirus E5 and E6 oncoproteins. Am J Pathol. 2008 Sep;173(3):682-8. doi: 10.2353/ajpath.2008.080280. Epub 2008 Aug 7. PMID: 18688031; PMCID: PMC2527066.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common mutation associated with the microscopy image of the thyroid shown?
questions.solution:
• The most common mutation associated with the microscopy image which shows the Orphan Annie eye nuclei which is characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the BRAF V600E mutation.
  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer.
  • It is also the most predominant thyroid cancer in children and iodine-sufficient areas. Radiation exposure is an important risk factor.
  • Genetics: BRAF gain-of-function mutation (V600E amino acid substitution) is commonly associated. RET/PTC rearrangements NTRK gene fusions.
Bavle RM. Orphan annie-eye nuclei. J Oral Maxillofac Pathol. 2013 May;17(2):154-5. doi: 10.4103/0973-029X.119737. PMID: 24250070; PMCID: PMC3830218.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution of the drug determines the loading dose of the drug.
Loading Dose = Volume of distribution x Desired steady-state plasma concentration.
When the time to reach a steady-state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of the drug in plasma to the target concentration.
Other options:
Option A: Clearance is used to determine the maintenance dose. Maintenance dose = clearance x desired steady-state plasma concentration.
Options C and D: Plasma half-life primarily determines the frequency of dosing, while bioavailability determines the route of administration. Though bioavailability may affect the dose necessary, it will not be the primary factor considered during the calculation of the loading dose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 23.

choices.text: Caffeine inhibits adenosine receptors, thus leading to awakening
Caffeine has no effect, and he can continue taking black coffee
Caffeine causes release of chemical from locus coeruleus that causes awakening
Caffeine has histaminic action in brain that leads to awakening

questions.text: Which of the following is the role of caffeine in the wakefulness?
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is 1. Caffeine inhibits adenosine receptors, thus leading to awakening

The role of caffeine in the wakefulness in this patient is that caffeine inhibits adenosine receptors, thus leading to awakening.
  • Caffeine, a commonly used stimulant, plays a significant role in promoting wakefulness and alertness. It functions primarily as an antagonist at adenosine A2A receptors in the brain.
  • Adenosine, a natural neuromodulator which accumulates in the basal forebrain area promotes sleepiness and relaxation by activating these receptors. By blocking adenosine A2A receptors, caffeine counteracts these sedative effects, thus helping to increase wakefulness and reduce fatigue.
  • In addition to its receptor antagonism, caffeine inhibits cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases, which leads to increased levels of cyclic AMP
  • (CAMP) in the brain. This action enhances the release of neurotransmitters such as influenced by factors such as metabolism, which varies widely among individuals.
  • For instance, smoking can reduce caffeine's half-life, making it clear from the body faster, while oral contraceptives can prolong its effects. Therefore, consuming caffeine close to bedtime, as in the case of drinking black coffee an hour before bed, can interfere with sleep by sustaining wakefulness and reducing the ability to fall asleep.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page No 546, 685.

questions.text: A 750-year-old female presented with Complain of unable to Control. She also has cognition decline and dementia. Which of the following drugs is useful for treating urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
For managing urinary incontinence in a 75-year-old female with cognitive decline and dementia, tolterodine is useful.
  • Tolterodine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist specifically effective for treating urinary incontinence. It exhibits selectivity for the urinary bladder, which helps to minimize side effects compared to other antimuscarinic agents.
  • This selectivity is beneficial for patients with cognitive decline or dementia, as it reduces the risk of adverse effects. Tolterodine is metabolized by CYP2D6, so its dosage may need adjustment based on individual CYP2D6 activity, making it a suitable option for managing urinary incontinence while minimizing potential side effects.
  • Other muscarinic antagonists for urinary incontinence include oxybutynin, trospium chloride, darifenacin, solifenacin, and fesoterodine.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 216.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a history suggestive of hyperthyroidism at 8 weeks of POG. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
• The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU).
  • It is because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole or methimazole. Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects such as: Aplasia cutis congenita • Choanal atresia • Treacheosopageal fistula • Fetal goiter
  • However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity.
  • It is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy.
  • The lowest effective antithyroid drug dose should be used throughout gestation. This is to maintain the maternal serum-free T4 level in the upper limit of the non-pregnant normal reference range.
  • Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker. It is used in thyroid storm preferentially as it blocks the peripheral conversion of inactive T4 to active form T3.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 797.

questions.text: Which of the following SNRI is used in the treatment of ADHD?
questions.solution:
The SNRI that can be used for the treatment of ADHD is Reboxetine.
  • Reboxetine, a SNRI has shown potential efficacy in treating ADHD, particularly in patients who do not respond to methylphenidate.
  • Common side effects of reboxetine include drowsiness, sedation, and gastrointestinal issues.
  • In the treatment of ADHD, pharmacotherapy is the primary approach, with central nervous system (CNS) stimulants being the most effective. Stimulants such as methylphenidate and amphetamine salts are commonly used due to their high efficacy in managing symptoms, although they come with risks of dependence and addiction.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page No 347.

questions.text: Which drug is used for maintenance therapy in opium addiction?
questions.solution:
• The drug used among the following options for maintenance therapy in opium addiction is buprenorphine.
  • Buprenorphine is a partial u-opioid agonist and an antagonist at b and K receptors. It is widely used both as an analgesic for chronic pain conditions, such as cancer pain, and as a treatment for opioid dependence, serving as an alternative to methadone.
  • Initial dosing typically starts at 2-4 mg daily, with adjustments made to stabilize the dose at approximately 12 to 16 mg/day. For opioid use disorder, effective management includes both withdrawal and long-term treatment strategies.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3572.

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent surgery has complaints of nausea and vomiting. He was prescribed a drug called aprepitant. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
• The class of drugs most preferred in patients suffering from postoperative nausea and Vomiting (PONV), following surgery are the NK1 antagonists like aprepitant.
  • Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors.
  • NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, fosaprepitant are examples of NK1 antagonists.
  • It also acts on the chemotrigger zone whose location is shown below.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: Identify the drug marked as 'Green Box' in the Flow chart.
questions.solution:
• The drug marked as 'Green Box' in the image is aminocaproic acid. 8-Aminocaproic acid, a lysine analogue that competes with plasminogen for binding sites on fibrin.
  • By blocking this interaction, 8- Aminocaproic acid prevents the conversion of plasminogen into plasmin, thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis.
  • This action makes it a useful agent for reversing the effects of fibrinolytic therapy. However, É›-Aminocaproic acid should be administered with caution as it can suppress intrinsic fibrinolytic activity, potentially leading to complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • To address this, fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate may be used to restore fibrin and clotting factors.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 596.

choices.text: 4 tablets of Artesunate 45mg + Sulphadoxine 1500mg +6 tablets of Primaquine 7.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 7.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + Sulphadoxine 1500mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg +6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg

questions.text: A man presents with mixed infection of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum. What is the dosage of the treatment given on the second day?
questions.solution:
• The dosage of the treatment given on the second day for mixed infection with Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum is 4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg.
  • For treating mixed infections of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum, the following treatment regimen is recommended.
  • This approach ensures comprehensive treatment by addressing both the blood stages of Plasmodium falciparum with ACT and the liver stages of Plasmodium vivax with Primaquine.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page No 310.

questions.text: Which drug is used to treat multiple myeloma that is known to cause reactivation of Herpes Zoster?
questions.solution:
• The drug used to treat multiple myeloma and that has the potential to cause reactivation of Herpes Zoster is bortezomib.
  • Bortezomib is an inhibitor of proteasome-mediated protein degradation. It is central to the treatment of multiple myeloma, both untreated and relapsed.
  • Bortezomib is given intravenously or subcutaneously and dosage depends upon the disease, route of administration, and the patient's history. 
  • Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, neutropenia, anemia, anorexia, nausea, limb pain, dizziness, etc. Other adverse events like cardiac tamponade, disseminated intravascular coagulation, toxic epidermal necrolysis, etc. have been reported.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 870.

questions.text: A patient presented with a slight loss of sensation along the ulnar nerve and a solitary nodule in the forearm. Intradermal antigen was injected. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient' s slight loss of sensation along the ulnar nerve, solitary forearm nodule, and histopathology showing well-defined granulomas indicate tuberculoid leprosy with a dermal test positive.



     
  • In tuberculoid leprosy, dermal granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone. It also shows high positivity of the lepromin skin (dermal) test.
  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin, cutaneous and peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. The most commonly affected peripheral nerves are the posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves. The most frequently involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve. It has a long incubation period, usually 2 to 12 years. It commonly presents as an area of numbness on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which could be a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.
  • The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy, as there are scarce granulomas to fil up the space. It is also seen in the borderline spectrum.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1384, 1388.

choices.text: Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluroquinolones
Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene

questions.text: For MDR-RR TB, what is the indication of short course bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to fluoroquinolones is an indication of a short course of bedaquline.
A shorter MDR-TB regimen of 6 months, BPaLM, is the treatment of choice for MDR/ RR TB as per the latest WHO guidelines.
A longer TB regimen has to be used instead of the shorter MDR TB regimen if:
  • XDR TB is suspected Pregnancy and lactation (Pretomanid is safe in pregnancy or breastfeeding)
  • Patients aged < 14 years
  • Resistance to the components of BPalM regimen
The BPaLM regimen, which consists four-drug combination – Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid and Moxifloxacin, has been proven to be safe, more effective and a quicker treatment option than the previous MDR-TB treatment procedure. While traditional MDR-TB treatments can last up to 20 months with severe side effects, BPaLM regimen can cure the drug-resistant TB in just six months with high treatment success rate.  



Reference: 

WHO consolidated guidelines on tuberculosis. Module 4: Treatment – drug-resistant tuberculosis treatment, 2022 update. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2022 (https://iris.who.int/handle/10665/365308).

Conradie F, Bagdasaryan TR, Borisov S, Howell P, Mikiashvili L, Ngubane N et al. Bedaquiline–pretomanid–linezolid regimens for drug-resistant tuberculosis. N Engl J Med. 2022;387:810–23. doi: https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa2119430.

choices.text: Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease

questions.text: A 21-year-old female complains of fever, headache and vomiting from the past 3 days. She has been living in the army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. On examination, she has neck stiffness and a maculopapular rash was noted over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is false about the disease she's likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features are suggestive of meningococcal meningitis and metronidazole is not the drug of choice.
  • The drug of choice is a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone. Chloramphenicol is used in patients with penicillin allergy. It is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a gram- negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococci.
  • Outbreaks usually occur in mass gatherings such as in army camps or hostel dorms. The risk of infection is increased in patients with terminal complement deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia and hypo-spleenism.
  • This is because opsonization by complement is a major mechanism by which the bacteria is cleared from the blood.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1100, 1102.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient came with chest pain associated with shortness of breath, and pedal edema. JVP showed following findings. On auscultation, he had high-pitched diastolic sound. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of the given clinical history and JVP showing rapid y descent is highly suggestive of  Constrictive pericarditis.
  • Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion.
  • The most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE.
  • Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.


Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 530, 531.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with hemoptysis. His current hemoglobin is 8g/dL (previous hemoglobin one week ago was 12g/dL). His bronchoalveolar lavage is reddish and his serum creatinine was 1.7mg/dL. He is diagnosed with ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis. Biopsy of the kidney revealed pauci-immune deposits and the absence of granulomas (Shown below) . Which of the following conditions is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis. The absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiates microscopic polyangitis from other forms of ANCA-associated vasculitis.
Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)- associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct forms:
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangitis, formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome (Css)
  • MPA and GPA often present very similarly, but MPA is primarily associated with myeloperoxidase autoantibodies while GPA is primarily associated with proteinase 3 autoantibodies. GPA also has a higher probability of ear, nose, and throat involvement and granulomatous inflammation in the respiratory tract.
  • For MPA or GPA patients with organ- or life-threatening disease, it is important to immediately start induction therapy with glucocorticoids combined with either rituximab or cyclophosphamide to prevent further organ damage.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2340.

questions.text: Match the following ECG waves with condition:
questions.solution:
The Correct answer is Option 1 Atrial flutter.
Atrial flutter rhythm is regular. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth- shaped waves known as flutter waves.
Atrial fibrillation rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these iregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, characteristic of atrial
fibrillation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1894, 1899, 1904.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and the tall T waves on ECG indicate hyperkalemia, which is commonly seen in a patient with chronic kidney disease.
The causes of hyperkalemia are given below - Intra- to extracellular shift
• Acidosis Hyperosmolality: radiocontrast, hypertonic dextrose, mannitol
• B2-Adrenergic antagonists (non-cardioselective agents)
• Digoxin and related glycosides (yellow oleander)
• Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
• Rapid tumor lysis Inadequate excretion
• Inhibition of the renin-angiotensin- aldosterone axis; which increases the risk of hyperkalemia when used in combination with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, renin-inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBS), blockade of the mineralocorticoid receptor(spironolactone, eplerenone), blockade of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) (amiloride, triamterene) 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1830, 1831.

choices.text: Increase in preload causes more reduction in myocardial oxygen demand than increase in afterload
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial 02 consumption
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure than aortic valve
Increase in myocardial 02 consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and angina episodes. On workup, she is found to have aortic stenosis. Which of the following findings favor the diagnosis of aortic stenosis over aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
• In evaluating the case of a 50-year-old female presenting with dyspnea and angina episodes, it is essential to differentiate between aortic stenosis (AS) and aortic regurgitation (AR).
  • The key factor to consider in aortic stenosis (AS) is that increased myocardial oxygen consumption is more closely associated with increased pressure work rather than increased volume.
  • AS is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease.
  • In AS, the heart works harder to overcome the elevated pressure gradient between the left ventricle (LV) and the aorta, leading to increased myocardial oxygen demand.
  • This is in contrast to AR, where the primary issue is volume overload rather than pressure overload.
* Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are:
1. Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
2. Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O, needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O, delivery.
3. Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1979, 1980.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-adrenergic blockers are beneficial for patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years?
questions.solution:
• The beta-adrenergic blocker that is useful in patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years is bisoprolol.
  • Bisoprolol is preferred for use in patients having heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
  • The exacerbation mentioned in the context of betablockers for heart failure refers to the potential worsening of heat failure symptoms in some patients, despite the overall benefits of these medications.
The only beta-blockers that have been proven to improve the survival of patients with HFrEF or chronic HF are -
  • Bisoprolol
  • Metoprolol
  • Carvedilol
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1940, 1941.

choices.text: Defibrillate, check rhythm and then start CPR
Defibrillate followed by CPR for 2min, and check rhythm
Stop CPR and do cardioversion at 2 joules/ kg

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with drowsiness and refusal to feed. On examination, the child is in a stuporous state. The ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG showing polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, which is a shockable rhythm, in a stuporous paediatric patient warrants immediate defibrillation followed by CPR for 2 minutes.
  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, especially in a paediatric patient, is often associated with severe underlying conditions and is a life- threatening rhythm disturbance.
  • Immediate defibrillation is critical for restoring a normal rhythm. After defibrillation, it is advisable to do CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm for the next round of shock to ensure adequate blood circulation and oxygenation. .
Reference: Viskin S, Chorin E, Viskin D, Hochstadt A, Schwartz AL, Rosso R. Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: Terminology, Mechanism, Diagnosis, and Emergency Therapy. Circulation. 2021 Sep 7;144(10):823-839. doi: 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.121.055783. Epub 2021 Sep 7. PMID: 34491774.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers given for all the patients
Lung transplant is the best treatment , if identified early
Lifestyle modification is the only possible approach

questions.text: An elderly patient, known case of scleroderma presented with shortness of breath . On examination , her right ventricular pressure was 75 mmHg and later on catheterization , pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was found to be 42 mmHg . Which of the following is true regarding her condition ?
questions.solution:
•  In this elderly patient with scleroderma presenting with elevated right ventricular pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure , is suggestive of scleroderma / systemic sclerosis ( SSC ) - associated pulmonary hypertension , and endothelin receptor antagonists improve the symptoms .
  • T. Ambrisartan + Tadalafil is most commonly used in PAH relating to SSc.
  • Right heart catheterization , the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension , confirms the condition when the mean pulmonary arterial pressure ( m PAP ) exceeds 20 mmHg .
  • In this elderly patient with scleroderma , elevated right ventricular pressure ( 70-80 mmHg ) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure ( 42 mmHg ) indicate severe pulmonary hypertension .
  • Interstitial lung Disease is a common association with Scleroderma.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2127, 2124.

questions.text: A man came to the emergency department after Road Traffic Accident with complaints of chest pain severe Respiratory Distress. An X - ray was done and is given below . What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• The type of breathing pattern observed in this patient with the X - ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggestive of a flail chest is paradoxical respiration .
  • A flail chest usually results from blunt trauma associated with 3 or more rib fractures in 2 or more places . It arises when these injuries cause a part of the chest wall to move independently of the rest of the chest wall .
  • It is diagnosed clinically by observing paradoxical respiration . On inspiration , the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced Inwards , and on expiration , it moves outwards . They are at higher risk of developing pneumothorax / hemothorax . CT scan is the gold standard investigation . 
  • Management includes oxygen administration , adequate analgesia ( including opiates ) or epidural analgesia , and physiotherapy . Intermittent positive pressure ventilation ( IPPV ) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient with bronchial asthma who has 3 episodes in the daytime and one episode at night time every week is prescribed salbutamol to use as and when required. FEV1 improved from 73% to 80% after taking bronchodilator (Post Broncho dilator Reversibility). What is the further treatment plan?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient with mild persistent asthma taking albuterol and FEV1 improving from 76% to 83% after taking bronchodilator, the patient should be prescribed fluticasone propionate 40mg BD either as Nasal spray or MDI.

Treatment guidelines for different types of asthma are given below:

Step 1 (intermittent) As needed low dose ICS + Formoterol
Step 2 (mild persistent) Daily low-dose ICs
Step 3 (moderate persistent) Daily low dose ICS+ LABA
Step 4 (severe persistent) Medium dose ICS + LABA +/- add-on therapy
Step 5 High dose ICS + LABA + oral steroids +/- add-on therapy

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page No 1965, 1967.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old presented with fever chills & cough with sputum for 7 days. Blood pressure was measured to be 160/90mmhg, pulse rate- 110bpm and respiratory rate - 18, spo2 - 88% at room air. An X-ray was done and shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

A. Tubercular pleural effusion
C. Community acquired pneumonia
D. Silicosis
B. Coal worker Pneumoconiosis
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette describes a case of community-acquired pneumonia. The findings of fever, chills, cough with expectoration, and chest X-ray findings of lobar involvement support the diagnosis.
  • Clinical features include acute onset fever, cough (with or without sputum production), and shortness of breath. In some cases, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, or increased work of breathing may be present on physical examination.
  • Diagnosis can be made using a chest X-ray. The presence of an infiltrate on a plain chest radiograph is considered the gold standard for diagnosing pneumonia.
  • Radiographic findings consistent with the diagnosis of CAP include lobar consolidations, interstitial infiltrates, and/or cavitations. 

Reference: Rider AC, Frazee BW. Community-Acquired Pneumonia. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2018 Nov;36(4):665-683. doi: 10.1016/j.emc.2018.07.001. Epub 2018 Sep 6. PMID: 30296998; PMCID: PMC7126690.

choices.text: Prevents alveoli collapse and atelectasis of lung

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery in the prone position is maintained on mechanical ventilation on NIV with PEEP of 6. What is the significance of using PEEP in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is Option 1. Prevents alveoli collapse and atelectasis of lung 
 
  • The significance of using positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the given clinical scenario is to help keep the alveoli open, preventing collapse (atelectasis), which is especially important in the prone position where certain lung regions might be more susceptible to collapse.
  • This is crucial in conditions where the lungs are prone to collapse, such as Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) or when the patient is in a prone position during surgery.
  • By maintaining open alveoli, PEEP improves gas exchange, which increases oxygen levels in the blood.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2033.

questions.text: A patient 60 years old Known Smoker with an acute exacerbation of COPD required mechanical ventilation and experienced Desaturation till 80%. Auscultation revealed vesicular breath sounds on the right side. Based on the chest radiography findings, what would you expect to hear on auscultation of the left side?
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is Option 1. Absent breath sounds

Absent breath sounds on the left side are expected in this case of left pneumothorax.
  • A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing lung collapse and preventing normal lung expansion, which leads to absent or diminished breath sounds over the affected area.
  • In patients with COPD, particularly during an acute exacerbation, the already weakened and hyperinflated lung tissue can rupture, leading to a pneumothorax.
  • This is a serious complication, mostly when mechanical ventilation is required, as the pressure from the ventilator can exacerbate the pneumothorax.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page No 1998, 2008.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with weight loss, hemoptysis and TTF-1 positivity. CXR and CT scan images are given below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Correct answer is Option 3. Adenocarcinoma

The clinical scenario cough, hemoptysis, weight loss with image showing immunohistochemical marker thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) positivity is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung.
  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in Women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma.
  • Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations. The majority express TTF-1, which is a protein required for normal lung development.
  • Napsin A is a new marker and is more sensitive and specific than TTE-1 in the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma.
  • Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 716, 721.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with partial compensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH =7.3, pC02 =16mmHg, HCO3-=6.3mmol/L, Na+- 135, K+- 4.5 CI-113.7, lactate was normal. Which of the following options correctly describes the condition?
questions.solution:
The Correct answer is Option 1. Metabolic acidosis with partial compensated respiratory alkalosis 

The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap.
It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation:
Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.3 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis
Step 2: HCO, is 6.3 mmol/L (Normal HCO; - 22-30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO, levels decrease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 360.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient presents with dyspnea and chest pain. The pleural fluid analysis shows pleural protein/ serum protein >0.5, and pleural LDH/ serum LDH > 0.4. What is the diagnosis?

A. Congestive heart failure 
B. Chronic kidney disease
C. Liver cirrhosis
D. Tuberculosis
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an exudative pleural effusion according to Light's criteria.
  • Among the given options, tuberculosis can lead to exudative pleural effusion. In any patient diagnosed with a pleural effusion, an effort should be made to find the cause. This requires a diagnostic thoracocentesis and analysis of the pleural fluid in terms of whether it is a transudate or an exudate based on Light's criteria: 1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • 2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • 3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal for serum If the pleural fluid meets one of these criteria, it is considered exudative pleural effusion. Sometimes, special investigations like ADA and cytology might be required to rule out tuberculosis and malignancy respectively.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2197, 2198.

questions.text: An infant presents with respiratory distress. He has a previous history of recurrent respiratory infections. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with the image suggestive of congenital malformations of the airway.
  • Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is a condition where more normal lung tissue is mixed with hamartomatous or dysplastic lung tissue, usualy confined to one lobe.
  • The lesion most likely originates from a maldevelopment of terminal bronchiolar structures caused by an embryologic injury that occurred prior to the 35th day of gestation.
  • Pneumothorax, recurrent respiratory infections, and respiratory distress can all manifest in patients during the newborn or early infancy period. One could mistake the lesion for a diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Treatment includes aspiration of macrocystic lesions, excision of the affected lobe for microcystic lesions, and infrequently, open foetal surgery for severely affected infants. For patients with symptoms in the postnatal period, Surgery is recommended.
Reference: Mehta PA, Sharma G. Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation. [Updated 2023 Aug 7]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2025 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551664/

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He was diagnosed as Acute pancreatitis. The laboratory results show serum triglyceride levels > 2000 mg/dl. Which deficiency could be contributing to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The elevated triglyceride levels and symptoms of acute pancreatitis are likely related to a deficiency in apolipoprotein C II.
  • Apolipoprotein C2 is a lipoprotein lipase cofactor that catalyzes cleavage of chylomicrons. Defective apo CIl results in type I hyperlipoproteinemia/ familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency. The resulting inactive lipoprotein lipase leads to slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, and low levels of LDL and HDL. Patients present with eruptive xanthomas and acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipoprotein lipase is an extracellular enzyme that is present in the capillary walls of most tissues. It is chiefly synthesized by the adipose tissue, and cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • A deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or apo C-ll leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial chylomicronemia which leads to an increased risk of acute pancreatitis.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 267.

choices.text: Injection vitamin K followed by dextrose infusion

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented to the emergency in an unconscious state. Relatives stated that he had a similar episode of binge drinking one week back. On examination, his glucose was 60 mg/dl. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids like IV dextrose.
  • Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:
  • 1. Wernicke' s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency.
  • It is characterized by: • Global confusion • Truncal ataxia Ophthalmoplegia • Horizontal nystagmus
  • 2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include: • Memory loss Confabulation
  • 3. Beriberi: It can present with: Dry beriberi: sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, muscle weakness; Wet beriberi: tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 534.

choices.text: Condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in thyrotoxic state
NO SPECS criteria is used for this condition
10% of isolated cases is present without hyperthyroidism

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient comes to the outpatient department with complaints of a Soft tissue Swelling in Neck. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female patient presenting with neck swelling weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and diffusely enlarged
thyroid gland is suggestive of Graves' disease with thyroid eye disease.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) does not improve simultaneously with improvement in the thyrotoxic state.
  • Graves' disease causes hyperthyroidism through thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) synthesized by lymphocytes in the thyroid gland, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. TSI antibodies stimulate the thyroid gland, causing hyperthyroidism.
  • Symptoms include hyperactivity, heat intolerance, sweating, palpitations, weakness, weight loss, increased appetite, and diarrhea. Signs include tachycardia, goiter, tremor, muscle weakness, and atrial fibrillation in the elderly.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2704, 2706.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with lethargy, Fatigue, tiredness. On examination, he has perioral hyperpigmentation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 beats/minute. Laboratory investigations revealed Na+ of 125mEq/L and K+ of 5.5mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment given to this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addisonian crisis) and IV hydrocortisone+ fludrocortisone is the most appropriate treatment for this condition.
  • Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitary pathology- lack of ACTH), or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH).
  • Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency worldwide.
  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in India.
  • Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to a precipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenal hemorhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands.
  • It presents with non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hypocalcemia, and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominal emergency.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2970- 2972.

questions.text: A young woman comes with weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors. She has exophthalmos on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical findings the most likely diagnosis is Graves' disease.
  • The hyperthyroidism of Graves' disease is caused by thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) that are synthesized in the thyroid gland as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes.
  • Clinical features of Graves' disease include hyperthyroid features like hyperactivity, irritability, dysphoria, heat intolerance and sweating palpitations, fatigue, and weakness, weight loss with increased appetite, diarrhea, polyuria, oligomenorrhea, loss of libido, tachycardia.
  • Graves ophthalmopathy is due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles because of marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration).
  • Radioactive iodine is also used as a treatment modality for hyperthyroidism in suitable patients but can aggravate Grave's ophthalmopathy.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2934, 2941, 2942.

questions.text: In a patient with type 1 diabetes with 3rd stage beta cell damage, which of the following situations is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
In type 1 diabetes mellitus, autoimmune positivity with dysglycemia indicates Stage 3, where clinical diabetes has become evident.
This advanced stage is characterized by significant beta cell destruction and insulin deficiency, resulting in symptomatic diabetes. Individuals with a genetic predisposition are exposed to a trigger that initiates an autoimmune process, leading to the production of islet autoantibodies and a progressive decline in beta cell function.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3099, 3100.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of easy fatiguability, anaemia, hyperpigmentation of knuckles, oral mucosa, palm and hands, and tachycardia. The blood pressure of the patient is 80/60 mm Hg and Na+ 13OmmHg. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a patient with easy fatiguability, skin and soft tissue hyperpigmentation, and a low blood pressure and hyponatremia is suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease).
  • Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis.
  • These patients are likely to develop other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease.
  • Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia) or infiltration.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2970, 2971.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease was having frequent attacks of renal colic. Which of the following diuretics is used?
questions.solution:
• For a hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease experiencing frequent attacks of renal colic, hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is often used.
  • Thiazide diuretics are particularly effective in cases of calcium oxalate kidney stones because they reduce urinary calcium excretion.
  • They work by acting on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron, where they inhibit the Na+/CI- co-transporter.
  • This inhibition decreases the intracellular sodium concentration, which, through compensatory mechanisms, leads to increased calcium reabsorption into the bloodstream.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2301.

choices.text: Blue Line -Liver, Red Line - Spleen, Brown line - Ovary, Yellow Line  - Testis
Blue Line- Brain, Red Line- Tonsils, Brown line - BMI, Yellow Line - Genital Organs
Blue Line- Brain, Red Line - somatic growth, Brown line - Ovary, Yellow Line - Height
Blue Line- Brain, Red Line- Waldeyer's ring, Brown line - somatic growth, Yellow Line- Testicular growth

questions.text: What is represented by each of the following growth curves?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is  Blue Line- Brain, Red Line- Waldeyer's ring, Brown line - somatic growth, Yellow Line- Testicular growth
  • Curve Blue : The neural growth(brain) attains 90% of the growth by the age of 2 years.
  • Curve Red: The tonsils are collections of Lymphatic tissue located within the pharynx. They collectively form a ringed arrangement, known as Waldeyer' s ring. Tonsils/lymphatic growth in children occur between 4- 8 years of age and then shrink down in adult age.
  • Curve Brown: Somatic growth shows a sigmoid curve, rapid growth in the initial years, and then during puberty.
  • Curve yellow: Testicular growth/Gonadal growth starts during puberty, before that the curve is Flat.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 217.

questions.text: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show a serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, low phosphate level of 2 mg/dL, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates the diagnosis of hypophosphatemic rickets because of the following features:
  • normal calcium levels (Normal: 9-11 mg/dL)
  • normal parathyroid hormone levels
  • decreased phosphate (Normal: 2.5-4.3 mg/dL)
  • elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (Normal: 33-96 U/L)
  • normal arterial blood gas levels
 

  •  Hypophosphatemic rickets: X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets are the most common genetic cause of rickets while the most common, overall is nutritional vitamin D deficiency.

  • PHEX gene (phosphate- regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin.

  • Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is also associated with impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate leading to its excess excretion. The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page No 338, 340.

choices.text: Using new threads to tie the ends of the umbilical cord
Wiping the baby's eyes from medial to lateral corner

questions.text: A mother delivers a baby in a rural area with the assistance of a skilled birth attendant. The attendant cuts the umbilical cord cleanly, ties the ends with new threads, bathes the baby with warm water, wipes the baby's eyes with a sterile wet cloth from the medial to lateral corner, and then hands the baby to the mother for skin-to-skin contact. Which of these steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect step is bathing the child with warm water immediately after birth.
It is generally recommended to delay bathing in the immediate newborn period to help maintain the baby' s body temperature and prevent hypothermia.


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page No 608, 610.

questions.text: After the age of 12, the boy had an intellectual disability. On examination, fingernail abrasions, excessive biting of lips, and increased levels of serum uric acid were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is Option B. Lesch-Nyhan disease 

The above clinical scenario with findings showing self-mutilation and laboratory values of hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl-transferase (HGPRT).
  • This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP).
  • Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid.
  • Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid. The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting,
  • developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 820, 1115.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a rare homozygous recessive condition presented with ectopia lentis. In the peripheral smear, there was no megaloblastic anemia. Later, he was found to have elevated homocysteine levels in the blood. Which of the following supplementations will help the patient?
questions.solution:
• The vitamin that can be used as supplementation in this patient with homocystinuria is pyridoxine (vitamin B6).
  • Classical homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disease most commonly caused by a deficiency of the cystathionine B-synthase.
  • The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an accumulation of homocysteine in the blood and a clinical syndrome of intellectual disability, subluxated ocular lenses, long and slender extremities, arachnodactyly, and arterial and venous thrombi.
  • The skeletal features of homocystinuria often mimic Marfan syndrome.
  • Folic acid and vitamin B12 deficiency can also lead to homocystinuria with megaloblastic anemia.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 703, 704.

questions.text: What is the type of inherited Disorder according to the given pedigree?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree chart points towards an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance.
Example: A Triad of micro-thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections points towards Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
 

* Extra Edge: Some features of X-linked recessive inheritance are:

  • only males are affected
  • there is no variation in expression, the disorder always follows a typical course
  • heterozygous females are clinically unaffected but carry the mutant gene
  • only rarely will a female manifest the signs of an X-linked disease; this is usually due to atypical lyonization, a new mutation in the other X chromosome, a carrier with Turner's syndrome, or X-autosome translocation
  • milder signs of X-linked disorders may evolve in the female due to normal lyonization

Approximately 290 X-linked recessive conditions are known, the following are the most frequently encountered:

  • red-green color blindness
  • non-specific X-linked mental retardation
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  • Becker muscular dystrophy
  • Haemophilia A (factor VIII)
  • Haemophilia B (factor IX)
  • X-linked icthythyosis
  • X-linked agammaglobulinaemia


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 141.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with short stature has primary amenorrhea and has not attained puberty yet. ldentify the chromosomal defect as shown in the image.
questions.solution:
• The given karyotyping image shows a "45 XO" abnormality, which is seen in Turner's syndrome.
  • Clinical features of Turner's syndrome include short stature, low posterior hairline, broad chest, widely spaced nipples, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, cubitus valgus, and pigmented nevi.
  • Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. The classical karyotype is 45, XO. Other variants have structural abnormalities of X chromosomes or mosaic patterns.
  • Some patients may present during infancy. They mainly present with oedema of the dorsum of the hand and foot due to lymphatic stasis. The most important cause of increased mortality in children with Turner's syndrome is cardiac abnormalities.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 166, 170.

questions.text: Identify the disease with the chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
• Paternal deletion of 15q12 is seen in Prader- Willi syndrome as shown in the image. Prader-Willi syndrome is a type of non- Mendelian mode of inheritance and genomic imprinting disorder.
  • It occurs due to the deletion of band 15g12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes.
  • It is characterized by mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features like a small upturned nose, narrow bifrontal distance and thin upper lip.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 178, 179.

questions.text: The Test Named "Urine Coproporphyrin" Is used to diagnose which disease ?
questions.solution:
The test for coproporphyrinogen levels is used as a screening test to diagnose lead poisoning.
Lead inhibits the enzymes delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase and ferrochelatase, which are involved in heme synthesis. ALA is converted to porphobilinogen by ALA dehydratase, inhibited by lead. So, serum porphobilinogen levels are decreased in lead poisoning.
* Laboratory findings include the following:
  • An elevated serum lead level
  • An elevated level of protoporphyrin in blood and elevated ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine Microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling in peripheral smear due to ineffective heme synthesis
  • Clinical features of chronic lead poisoning include facial pallor, anemia, basophilic stippling of red cells, blue lines in the gums, and retinal stippling.
  • In the later phase, the findings are colic abdominal pain, constipation, nerve palsy, encephalopathy, and disturbance of the genito-urinary and cardiovascular systems.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 309.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child from a southern Indian state, hailing from a poor family, presents with rough and scaly skin. The child's diet lacks vegetables and fruits. After treatment with linseed oil, Vitamin A, and Vitamin B, the symptoms subsided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cutaneous lesions with rough and scaly skin, with dietary history stating lack of vegetables and fruits is suggestive of phrynoderma.
  • Phrynoderma are keratotic follicular papules commonly present over the elbows and knees.
  • They can also extend to the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. It is also known as toad skin, due to the rough cone-shaped elevated papules. It can caused by deficiency of vitamins A, B complex, C, and E and essential fatty acids.
Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 63.7.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with features of lethargy, and poor oral intake. On examination, a cataract was seen. Urine Benedict's test was positive but Image for Glucose given . What will be the enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with lethargy, and poor oral intake, with examination revealing a cataract and urine benedict's test was positive but negative for glucose, is suggestive of classical galactosemia and enzyme deficient is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose).
  • The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate to uridine diphosphate galactose. This leads to the accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 189, 191.

questions.text: A child presents to you with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A trephine biopsy aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing Gaucher's cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher's disease.
  • The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism caused due to a deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase.
  • It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder and the mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive.
  • There is an accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, and other tissues.
  • There are three clinical subtypes - type l (chronic non-neuronopathic), type ll (acute neuronopathic), and type ll (intermediate). Clinical features include anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and neurological features depending on the subtype.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: A patient with a family history of coronary heart disease presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum LDL to be 280 mg/dL and triglyceride levels was 398 mg/dl. What is the likely defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas, elevated serum LDL and elevated serum triglycerides points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia and is due to a defect in LDL receptors.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (type lla hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol.
  • Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.
  • Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with • LDL > 190 mg/dl, • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or • Premature coronary artery disease.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after ingesting 10 tablets of Phenobarbital. Which of the following components of the ETC is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
• Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that inhibits complex I to Q of the electron transport chain. Complex I of the electron transport chain is NADH-Q oxidoreductase.
  • It oxidizes NADH and reduces coenzyme Q. Phenobarbital inhibits complex I to Q so that the electrons will not be able to be transferred from NADH to coenzyme Q, which is the first step in the electron transport chain.
  • As a result, the rate of oxygen consumption will decrease. The electron transport chain (ETC) represents the final pathway through which electrons, originating from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids, are channeled toward a final reaction with oxygen to produce water and ATP.
  • The ETC complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 122-127, 159.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of persistent delayed developmental milestones, and hyperpigmented macular lesions on the body which are more pronounced on exposure to sunlight. What is the error in DNA multiplication?

A. Base excision repair
B. Nucleotide excision repair
C. DNA mismatch repair
D. Homologous recombination
questions.solution:
• The history points to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair.
  • UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase.
  • The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.
  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. This leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 370.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man came to the OPD with a febrile illness of 4 days, associated with abdominal tenderness, Generalised Bodyache and diarrhoea. He had a fever with bradycardia and BP was noted as 110/70 mmHg. He lives in a crowded neighborhood with poor sanitation where many others have reported similar complaints recently. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of fever with relative bradycardia, abdominal tenderness, and similar cases in the neighborhood suggests enteric fever.
It is caused by Salmonella typhi or paratyphi. Out of the given options, blood culture is the most sensitive test in this patient.
Diagnosis of enteric fever:
  • Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week than in the subsequent weeks. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.
  • Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titres of H and0 agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.
  • Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.
  • Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.
  • Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week. The culture of duodenal aspirate may yield positive results when bone marrow culture is inconclusive.
  • Relative bradycardia is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than expected for a given rise in body temperature. (Faget's sign)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  303, 304.

questions.text: A male patient comes to you with a history of UTI, the cause of which is suspected to be bacteria. Which of the following is used by the bacteria for adherence?
questions.solution:
The Correct answer is Option 3. Fimbriae
Bacteria utilise fimbriae for adherence. Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based the function of ordinary pili and sex pili.

Functions of pili:
  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic
  • bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for
  • the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, in which transfer of genetic material occur
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  20.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer comes with complaints of high-grade fever with chills, retro-orbital pain and conjunctival suffusion. On examination, he has severe calf tenderness. Lab examination shows hypokalemia and neutropenia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette of high-grade fever with chills, retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, severe calf tenderness, and laboratory findings of hypokalemia and neutropenia is suggestive of leptospirosis.
  • Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia.
  • The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back.
Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by triad of:
  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury
Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 25.76.

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of oysters comes with complaints of nausea, vomiting and crampy abdominal pain. The culture of the organism showed the Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahemolyticus.
On Wagatsuma agar (blood agar with 2% salt), pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is due to a heat stable hemolysin. They produce green-colored colonies on the TCBS agar as they do not ferment sucrose. 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 4th Edition, Page No 302, 417.

questions.text: A man is having petechial rashes with a previous history of meningitis. He was vaccinated at the age of 5 years. Now, Brudzinski and Kernig's signs were positive. Microscopy showed gram negative diplococci. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of fulminant meningococcemia.
  • The organism causing this condition is Neisseria meningitidis. Neisseria meningitidis is an aerobic, gram- negative, nonmotile diplococcus that is catalase and oxidase-positive. It oxidizes glucose and maltose but not lactose or sucrose.
  • The bacteria typically spread from the nasopharynx to the meninges via the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve following an initial flu-like infection.

  • Meningococcemia often starts with acute fever, chills, malaise, and a petechial rash. As the disease advances, symptoms of meningitis, such as severe headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck, may develop, potentially progressing to coma within a few hours.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1102.

choices.text: Biofilm does not affect susceptibility to antibiotics
Biofilm can be washed off from the catheter
Biofilm offers resistance so catheter is to be removed

questions.text: A patient who has a central line on long-term IV antibiotics develops a fever. Blood cultures show Staphylococcus epidermidis along with biofilm formation. Which of the following describes its features of antibiotic resistance?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with a central line on long-term antibiotics along with culture showing biofilm formation, the correct measure is to remove the catheter as biofilm offers resistance.
  • Biofilms are structured microcolonies of organisms that are enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx matrix.
  • The biofilms are attached to solid surfaces and form a slimy layer over them.
  • Organisms that produce biofilm include: Staphylococcus epidermidis on medical devices and implants Streptococcus viridians on heart valves • Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infections, Staphylococcus aureus on catheters • Legionella pneumophila colonization of hospital water systems.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  77, 209.

questions.text: A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications. She also has hydrocephalus. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• The presence of bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus in a neonate is suggestive of congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • The characteristic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation. The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy. The causative agent is Toxoplasma gondi, an obligate intracellular protozoan.
  • The diagnosis is made by the detection of lgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies. 
  • Pyrimethamine- sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetal infection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 1870.

choices.text: Test must be repeated with a fresh specimen
Diagnose and treat as urinary tract infection
Normal skin commensal grown on culture that needed to proved

questions.text: A young sexually active female presented with a symptomatic UTI. Urinalysis and cultures showed novobiocin-resistant coagulase negative staphylococcus with a count of 10^4 cells/ HPF. What is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
• A young sexually active female presenting with a symptomatic UTI and urinalysis and cultures showing novobiocin-resistant coagulase- negative staphylococcus with a count of 10^4 cells/HPF should be diagnosed as a urinary tract infection and should be treated.
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a gram- positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus. It is non-pigmented, novobiocin resistant, and nonhemolytic on blood agar.
  • It is a leading cause of cystitis in women. It is a part of the normal flora of human skin and periurethral area and thus causes cystitis in sexually active Women.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  208.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for syndromic diagnosis of infectious Diseases like meningitis?
questions.solution:
• Multiplex PCR can be used for syndromic diagnosis of meningitis.
  • A syndromic diagnosis is a method of diagnosing infectious diseases that uses a single test to screen for multiple pathogens that could be causing a specific set of symptoms.
  • Multiplex PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a variation of the standard PCR technique that allows simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single reaction. It uses more than one set of primers (specific to different target sequences) to amplify different DNA fragments at the same time.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  663, 664.

questions.text: A thalassemia patient has received multiple blood transfusions. Aplastic crisis can occur in this patient due to infection from?
questions.solution:
Aplastic crisis in this patient is triggered by parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs is shortened.
  • The immune response clears the virus in 1-2 weeks. It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle- cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and paleness with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present.
  • Parvovirus B19 infection occurs usually in children 5-10 years causing erythema infectiosum. It is also known as the fifth disease. It begins as a prominent erythema of the cheeks- slapped cheek disease, spreading to the trunk and limbs, followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. Fever and mild constitutional symptoms may accompany the rash.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 4th Edition, Page No 556.

questions.text: A farmer from South East India presents with fever, respiratory distress and neurological deficits. The vector of the causative organism is shown below. what is the associated organism?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with the vector bat is suggestive of infection from the nipah virus.
  • Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus.
  • It is a zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to- human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family.
  • The clinical manifestations include asymptomatic subclinical infection, acute respiratory infection, and fatal encephalitis.
  • There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 4th Edition, Page No 343, 718.

questions.text: A patient receiving chemotherapy develops pneumonia with skin lesions. Microscopy of specimen from skin lesions showed broad based budding with a thick capsule. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case of an immunocompromised patient with pneumonia and skin lesions, the microscopy of specimens from skin lesions showing broad based budding with a thick capsule suggests the diagnosis of Blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis.
Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin.


Healthy individuals may experience a range of symptoms from mild pulmonary illness to more severe forms of pneumonia.
It is more commonly observed in males aged 30-50 years, possibly due to occupational or recreational exposures.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  610, 611.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and perianal itching for the last 3 days. The mother said she noticed a white thread-like structure in the child's night clothes. She collected the worm and brought it to the clinician. A perianal swab was collected. Microscopy of the swab and the worm are shown in the images. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
